q: What are the symptoms of retinal migraines?
a: Symptoms of retinal migraines include vision loss, blind spots, headache, blurred vision, flashing lights, and nausea.

q: When should I seek urgent medical help for retinal migraines?
a: You should seek urgent medical help if you experience sudden vision loss, extremely painful headache, problems speaking or remembering, dizziness, seizures, or weakness on one side of the body.

q: What are the treatment options for retinal migraines?
a: Treatment options for retinal migraines include avoiding triggers, taking painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen, medications to relieve nausea, preventive medications like topiramate or amitriptyline, and acupuncture.

q: What can cause retinal migraines?
a: Possible causes of retinal migraines include stress, caffeine, alcohol, dehydration, smoking, high blood pressure, bending over, low blood sugar, and certain types of hormonal contraception.

q: What can I do if I get retinal migraines?
a: If you get retinal migraines, you can try lying down in a dark room, staying hydrated, maintaining a healthy diet, exercising regularly, managing stress, avoiding triggers like caffeine and alcohol.

q: Are retinal migraines common?
a: Retinal migraines are less common than other types of migraines.

q: How long does vision loss usually last in retinal migraines?
a: Vision loss in retinal migraines usually lasts around 10 to 20 minutes but can sometimes last up to 1 hour.

q: When should I see a doctor for retinal migraines?
a: You should see a doctor if your retinal migraines are getting worse, occurring more often, or if there's a change to your usual symptoms.

q: Do I need treatment for retinal migraines if I don't have them often?
a: Treatment for retinal migraines is not usually needed if you do not have them very often.

q: When should I call 999 for retinal migraines?
a: You should call 999 if you experience sudden and extremely painful headache, problems speaking or remembering, sudden vision loss, dizziness, seizures, or weakness on one side of the body.

q: What are the symptoms of retinal migraines?
a: Symptoms of retinal migraines include vision loss, blind spots in vision, headache, blurred vision, seeing flashing lights or patterns, feeling sick or vomiting.

q: When should I seek urgent medical help for retinal migraines?
a: You should seek urgent medical help if you experience vision problems for the first time, such as a blind spot in your vision, sudden headache, sudden loss of vision, dizziness, confusion, seizure, high temperature with stiff neck or rash, or sudden weakness on one side of the body.

q: What should I do if I have retinal migraines frequently?
a: If you have retinal migraines frequently, you should see a GP who may recommend avoiding triggers, taking painkillers, and trying preventive medicines or acupuncture. In severe cases, you may be referred to a neurologist for further tests and treatment.

q: What are the possible causes of retinal migraines?
a: Retinal migraines can be caused by factors like stress, caffeine and alcohol, dehydration, smoking, high blood pressure, bending over, low blood sugar, and certain types of hormonal contraception. Keeping a migraine diary can help identify triggers.

q: How can I manage retinal migraines?
a: To manage retinal migraines, you can try resting or lying down in a dark room, staying hydrated, maintaining a healthy diet and regular meal times, exercising regularly and getting enough sleep, managing stress levels, and avoiding triggers such as caffeine and alcohol.

q: Should retinal migraines be treated?
a: Treatment for retinal migraines is not usually needed if they occur infrequently. However, if they occur frequently, a GP may recommend lifestyle changes, painkillers, anti-nausea medications, preventive medicines, or acupuncture. In severe cases, referral to a neurologist may be necessary.

q: What can I do if I experience temporary vision loss in one eye?
a: If you experience temporary vision loss in one eye, it could be a symptom of retinal migraine. It is advisable to seek medical advice to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.

q: Can retinal migraines occur without a headache?
a: Yes, it is possible to experience the eye symptoms of retinal migraines without a headache. If you are experiencing such symptoms, it is recommended to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

q: Can retinal migraines be prevented?
a: Retinal migraines can sometimes be prevented by avoiding triggers such as stress, caffeine, and alcohol. Additionally, certain medications or lifestyle modifications may be recommended by a healthcare professional to help prevent migraines.

q: When should I call emergency services for retinal migraines?
a: Emergency services should be called if you experience sudden and extremely painful headache, problems speaking or remembering, sudden loss of vision, dizziness, seizures, high temperature with a stiff neck or an unexplained rash, or sudden weakness on one side of the body or face.
